subject: Add recipe for IBM vpd parser
commitMessage:
Add recipe for IBM vpd parser

The recipe does the following
    - inherits dependent packages
    - installs the ibm-read-vpd application
    - adds the service file
    - enables the flag to build the ibm-read-vpd app
    - installs the udev parser
    - installs the vpd inventory JSON

The service file is templated and is driven by the udev rule, the
template argument is the path to the vpd file, the service file
triggers the ibm-read-vpd parser application along with the template
argument as a parameter. The ibm-read-vpd application parses
the IBM based fru vpd and updates it into D-Bus.

Signed-off-by: Jinu Joy Thomas <jinu.joy.thomas@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I004d46d48932e3a5acce34cc6923979929be8bb8

it should be due to the fact that the IBM vpd Parser is not in yet and so my changes hit the road block for rainier.

Patch Set 8:

We already have a recipe for this repo.  Why are we adding another one?

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> We already have a recipe for this repo.  Why are we adding another one?

The existing recipe adds udev rule that is not needed by the IPZ parser. This made us "remove" the udev rule file in do_install_append_rainier (see PS1).

Since that seemed like a workaround, we felt it would be cleaner if the IBM VPD parser had its own recipe and package group.

This is still failing to compile on downstream systems. We shouldn't merge until that is fixed.

Patch Set 13:

(2 comments)

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> > Patch Set 8:
> > 
> > We already have a recipe for this repo.  Why are we adding another one?
> 
> The existing recipe adds udev rule that is not needed by the IPZ parser. This made us "remove" the udev rule file in do_install_append_rainier (see PS1).
> 
> Since that seemed like a workaround, we felt it would be cleaner if the IBM VPD parser had its own recipe and package group.

I think a new package, not an entirely new recipe is likely more appropriate here.  You can leave the existing openpower-vpd-parser package as it is and add a new package with the ibm-vpd-parser application, to be installed wherever it is needed.

and about that (where is it needed)...can you help me remember what the difference between the openpower-vpd-parser and ibm-read-vpd parser applications are?  Just out of curiosity why did we create an entirely new application and not just add the support to openpower-vpd-parser?

Patch Set 13:

(2 comments)

> Patch Set 13:
> 
> (2 comments)
> 
> > Patch Set 8:
> > 
> > > Patch Set 8:
> > > 
> > > We already have a recipe for this repo.  Why are we adding another one?
> > 
> > The existing recipe adds udev rule that is not needed by the IPZ parser. This made us "remove" the udev rule file in do_install_append_rainier (see PS1).
> > 
> > Since that seemed like a workaround, we felt it would be cleaner if the IBM VPD parser had its own recipe and package group.
> 
> I think a new package, not an entirely new recipe is likely more appropriate here.  You can leave the existing openpower-vpd-parser package as it is and add a new package with the ibm-vpd-parser application, to be installed wherever it is needed.

Could you point to some bitbake documentation on how to define a new package within an existing recipe?

> 
> and about that (where is it needed)...can you help me remember what the difference between the openpower-vpd-parser and ibm-read-vpd parser applications are?  Just out of curiosity why did we create an entirely new application and not just add the support to openpower-vpd-parser?

There are a few differences; the IBM VPD parser app will:

* Support IPZ and keyword VPD formats
* Support for large keywords (those starting with a '#')
* It is runtime JSON driven as opposed to build time YAML config driven.
* Builds different interface-property maps to publish to PIM.
* Will support ECC checking.

While it certainly is *possible* to add all of these under a single app binary, I think it is far more cleaner to have a separate application as it allows for different command line arguments and future enhancements.

> 
> There are a few differences; the IBM VPD parser app will:
> 
> * Support IPZ and keyword VPD formats
> * Support for large keywords (those starting with a '#')
> * It is runtime JSON driven as opposed to build time YAML config driven.
> * Builds different interface-property maps to publish to PIM.
> * Will support ECC checking.
> 
> While it certainly is *possible* to add all of these under a single app binary, I think it is far more cleaner to have a separate application as it allows for different command line arguments and future enhancements.

I would still think having a different recipe is better in this case as it would actually be over populated and we also would not want to use the same recipe, just because the code is being used. We would have a lot of items once the whole IBM vpd parser is done and keeping it separate will help us in. many ways even when we move to entity manager, open power-vpd-parser will still be the same old recipe. I am not sure what the issue is for having a new recipe.

Patch Set 13:

I do see a few examples on how recipes can define new packages (in addition to the default ${PN}-* ones), but don't you think it is cleaner to instead have a new recipe add portions of the application to the image?

Are there benefits to doing this as a package in the existing recipe that I am missing?

Patch Set 13:

> Could you point to some bitbake documentation on how to define a new package within an existing recipe?

It is pretty straightforward:

 PACKAGE_BEFORE_PN = " ibm-vpd-parser"
 FILES_ibm-vpd-parser = "$bindir/ibm-vpd-parser"

should do it.

> > and about that (where is it needed)...can you help me remember what the difference between the openpower-vpd-parser and ibm-read-vpd parser applications are?  Just out of curiosity why did we create an entirely new application and not just add the support to openpower-vpd-parser?
> 
> There are a few differences; the IBM VPD parser app will:
> 
> * Support IPZ and keyword VPD formats
> * Support for large keywords (those starting with a '#')
> * It is runtime JSON driven as opposed to build time YAML config driven.
> * Builds different interface-property maps to publish to PIM.
> * Will support ECC checking.
> 
> While it certainly is *possible* to add all of these under a single app binary, I think it is far more cleaner to have a separate application as it allows for different command line arguments and future enhancements.

ok, thanks for catching me up.  IMO different command line arguments for reading different types of vpd might not be optimal from a usability pov. - I think users would appreciate being able to use the same application and command line options to interact with the vpd logic... regardless of what format it is stored in.

but I don't maintain openpower-vpd-parser, so this just me waxing philosophical.

Patch Set 13:

Hi Jinu

> I would still think having a different recipe is better in this case as it would actually be over populated

can you elaborate on what is meant by over populated?

> and we also would not want to use the same recipe, just because the code is being used. 

why?

> We would have a lot of items once the whole IBM vpd parser is done and keeping it separate will help us in. many ways

like how?  Can you give me some examples of how it will help?

> even when we move to entity manager, open power-vpd-parser will still be the same old recipe. 

Agreed...but how is the relevant to having a new recipe vs having a new package?

> I am not sure what the issue is for having a new recipe.

I think the biggest reason is that conceptually what is being done here is a well established pattern in OE, and the way to implement that is with a package.  Unless there are reasons to deviate from that norm, I don't want to.  You'll have to convince me that there is a valid reason to do this differently in the openpower-vpd-parser case.  You are welcome to try but it is going to be very hard :-)

Patch Set 13:

(2 comments)

oops - just realized I missed two questions.
Abandoned
These seem to belong to another commit - the one that would enable the ipz parser app.
did not want to change the existing main bb file as this comes in only for rainier and as team we decided having the machine specific adds will be done via the bbappend file only and so this is here.
My comment was something else though - this change does not correspond with what the commit message this does.
Maybe it's just a commit message change that's needed :) Something that stresses more on the fact that a new IBM vpd parser app is being added and the thing about udev rules can be in the details.
sure just seeing currently why it is failing , will check with you more on this.
This seems a bit odd to to. Maybe this rule file should be installed only on the systems that require it, instead of all OP.
agree, just that the open power repo is used by many outside our control so did not want to create a ripple , so was decided to do here.
If we verify it for one system (for eg Witherspoon), we know we've done it right. This change seems like a workaround.
yup I agree, may need to see if we can find a better way.
can we please add this to openpower-vpd-parser and have it installed via make install?
That'd make it difficult (impossible?) to install different rules on a per-recipe basis.
my take is that it would be better not to over populate the openpower-vpd-parser recipe.

you can use meson options to configure which template to SYSTEMD_WANT.  You are right - it would be much simpler if we had just a single application and single template that worked in all situations to install.

> my take is that it would be better not to over populate the openpower-vpd-parser recipe.

Its only one line to add a PACKAGECONFIG.

Most projects have stopped hosting their systemd unit files in the metadata and moved them to the project source itself.

To that end, can we please add this to openpower-vpd-parser and have it installed via make install?
How do we handle cases where the service dependencies and the executables being invoked are system dependent if we add these to the project's repo?

would be better not to over populate the open-power repo , initially it was added and it was like a workaround and so was moved out to a recipe. This will be cleaner until we move to entity manager and so we will not have any residue left in the open-power recipe.

> How do we handle cases where the service dependencies and the executables being invoked are system dependent if we add these to the project's repo?

What is an example of a system dependent executable?  Ideally we don't have those at all?

As far as system specific unit dependencies I'd like to not have those either.  Is there any reason the dependency could not be added on all systems?  The overall goal is to have as much code as possible act the same from one OpenBMC machine to the next.

If we absolutely must have a system specific dependenccy, that can be accomplished with systemd overrides on a per system basis.  but if we get into that situation there are probably better alternatives available.
